For further testing context I also ran woodpeckers swift-bench action against both civetweb and beast configured octopus deployments with 4K and 4M block sizes - the metrics returned are not useful (as the environment is virtualised and has limited network bandwidth) but there where no errors so functionally looks good.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2021-06-17 10:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

LGTM in general, thanks, but I agree that we could refactor a bit the arch+release:frontend compatibility matrix'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2021-07-06 13:15:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2021-07-06 13:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Aurelien

Your comment made me reflect on the complexity of that code block - its in actual fact to clear functions - one that resolves the best configuration option if the user does not provide one and another that validates any end-user provided value.

So having a similar/same conditional in both code paths is OK IMHO - however I have split this into two distinct functions to make this distinction very clear.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2021-07-06 13:19:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2021-07-07 08:28:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2021-07-07 08:50:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Enable support for beast frontend

Introduce support for the beast web frontend for the Ceph
RADOS Gateway which brings improvements to speed and scalability.

Default behaviour is changed in that for Octopus and later
(aside from some unsupported architectures) beast is enabled by
default; for older releases civetweb is still used.

This may be overridden using the 'http-frontend' configuration
option which accepts either 'beast' or 'civetweb' as valid
values.  'beast' is only supported with Ceph Mimic or later.

Closes-Bug: 1865396
Change-Id: Ib73e58e21219eca611cd4293da69bf80040f5803

'}, {'created': '2021-07-15 14:17:11.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing classes to cinderclient.v3

The QuotaSet class was never added to cinderclient.v3.quotas, and
the VolumeTransfer class was never added to cinderclient.v3.
volume_transfers.

This issue is preventing Horizon from using cinderclient.v3 classes
only.

Change-Id: Iabb8b2b36e76849af1d1662c628baaeada06ddb8
'}]
commit_message:
Add missing classes to cinderclient.v3

The QuotaSet class was never added to cinderclient.v3.quotas, and
the VolumeTransfer class was never added to cinderclient.v3.
volume_transfers.

This issue is preventing Horizon from using cinderclient.v3 classes
only.

Change-Id: Iabb8b2b36e76849af1d1662c628baaeada06ddb8

Gyansham was working on a different approach for tempest. I'm actually not sure of the current state. This was partly just to see how horribly things would break if we did disable v2 at this point, and I should probably just abandon it.

I think I will leave it open for awhile though to see if it instigates any progress though.

As far as not registering the v1 endpoint, that shouldn't really make any difference here."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-05-10 18:47:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 21863, 'date': '2018-05-10 20:15:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This is going to kill the gate since there are still parts of nova using the legacy attachment flow which uses the v2 APIs for things like os-initialize_connection/os-attach/reserve/os-terminate_connection/os-detach - those are all in the v3.0 API though, right? Maybe the cinderclient usage in nova isn't using the 3.0 client for everything? These are the main things I know about in nova that are trying to get us off the legacy attachment flow:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541420/

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/549130/"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-09-22 19:56:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Nova can continue to make the existing calls, just with using v3 instead. Base v3 is the same as v2. commit_message:
Default API v2 to disabled

We have deprecated v2 for some time now, but defaulted config
to have it still enabled. Switching to be disabled by default.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/676505
Change-Id: I61eb53a4a3c20d8b520c5344f8148ff27308ba13

Hi Brian,

I was just going through the cinder/api/v3/volumes.py file and found below imports and class inheritance.

from cinder.api.v2 import volumes as volumes_v2

class VolumeController(volumes_v2.VolumeController):
    """The Volumes API controller for the OpenStack API V3."""

My query is the above import and class inheritance needs to updated? as part of remove v2 support.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-05-20 13:04:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> Hi Brian,
> 
> I was just going through the cinder/api/v3/volumes.py file and found below imports and class inheritance.
> 
> from cinder.api.v2 import volumes as volumes_v2
> 
> class VolumeController(volumes_v2.VolumeController):
>     """The Volumes API controller for the OpenStack API V3."""
> 
> My query is the above import and class inheritance needs to updated? as part of remove v2 support.

@Girish: see the discussion from the PTG:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CinderXenaPTGSummary#Removing_the_Block_Storage_API_v2

We're going to handle the cinder classes differently from the cinderclient.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-05-25 12:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2021-05-17 22:36:39.000000000', 'message': 'Remove v2 support from the shell

Also removes the v2 support from the generic client and restores a
skipped test.

Additionally, the cinderclient.tests.v2.test_availablity_zone module
depends on the v2.shell class, so move that module to v3, update the
v3 AvailablityZone class, and make appropriate adjustments to the
tests and test fixtures.

commit_message:
Remove v2 support from the shell

Also removes the v2 support from the generic client and restores a
skipped test.

Additionally, the cinderclient.tests.v2.test_availablity_zone module
depends on the v2.shell class, so move that module to v3, update the
v3 AvailablityZone class, and make appropriate adjustments to the
tests and test fixtures.

Change-Id: I7a3cca15f5944141d510a75af6684221c297963b

commit_message:
Replace deprecated import of ABCs from collections

ABCs in collections should be imported from collections.abc and direct
import from collections is deprecated since Python 3.3[1].

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.html
---
Deprecated since version 3.3, will be removed in version 3.10: Moved
Collections Abstract Base Classes to the collections.abc module.
For backwards compatibility, they continue to be visible in this module
through Python 3.9.
---

Change-Id: I4ded939b007f979ec81c2389ac1912115c555c3c

The nondurable_purge_delay option was introduced in [1] to prevent the

commit_message:
reconstructor: retire nondurable_purge_delay option

The nondurable_purge_delay option was introduced in [1] to prevent the
reconstructor removing non-durable data files on handoffs that were
about to be made durable. The DiskFileManager commit_window option has
since been introduced [2] which specifies a similar time window during
which non-durable data files should not be removed. The commit_window
option can be re-used by the reconstructor, making the
nondurable_purge_delay option redundant.

The nondurable_purge_delay option has not been available in any tagged
release and is therefore removed with no backwards compatibility.

[1] Related-Change: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0
[2] Related-Change: I5f3318a44af64b77a63713e6ff8d0fd3b6144f13
Change-Id: I1589a7517b7375fcc21472e2d514f26986bf5079

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-16 08:46:52.000000000', 'message': 'Force immediate NTP time sync with chronyd at IPA startup

In order to make sure we have the correct time early, e.g.
by the time we create a TLS certificate, this patch proposes
to force an immediate NTP update when using chronyd. While
the previous approach uses the passed NTP server as well, the
update may happen only after chronyd has performed measurements
(which may be too late).

Story: #2009058
Task: #42843

Change-Id: I6edafe8edeb8549f324959e7a1ec175c3049a515
'}]
commit_message:
Force immediate NTP time sync with chronyd at IPA startup

In order to make sure we have the correct time early, e.g.
by the time we create a TLS certificate, this patch proposes
to force an immediate NTP update when using chronyd. While
the previous approach uses the passed NTP server as well, the
update may happen only after chronyd has performed measurements
(which may be too late).

Story: #2009058
Task: #42843

Change-Id: I6edafe8edeb8549f324959e7a1ec175c3049a515

is also False in the configuration.

commit_message:
Redfish: Skip non-RAID controllers for RAID

Avoid processing non-RAID controllers as they cannot be
used for RAID operations to save some time and requests
and avoid possible errors later if non-RAID disks
are picked up for configuration.

Related to: I369bdbb17064baf34f90e864d0ece600529de509

Change-Id: I728f03dc829fb76cad9804c8f8df20810307ce2c
(cherry picked from commit c779be9f7d18779d9befed9c6d92253d50448a12)

commit_message:
Fix Docker build

The default nodeset was just changed to focal [1], which in the absence
of the python-is-python3 package doesn't provide a python binary.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/opendev/base-jobs/+/789098

Change-Id: I2b208db2b7b34da034071a4fc0c5d49768b6dad3
(cherry picked from commit 31152e169dad086c8b5be19473c142f90baa2961)

subject: set glance user explicitly in manila-share.conf
messages:
[{'account_id': 33307, 'date': '2021-04-20 09:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-04-20 14:03:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think that's the right approach. Mark suggested to make the glance_keystone_user variable global."}, {'account_id': 33307, 'date': '2021-04-20 14:10:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> I don't think that's the right approach. Mark suggested to make the glance_keystone_user variable global.


I guess the question is, which way do you want it. Do we want it set globaly? or do we want it hard coded. If you look at the config file, cinder is hard coded. If we don't want hard coded names then we should move all of hard coded names into the global variable file. But others are going to have to identify what impact that might have."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-04-21 08:51:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > I don't think that's the right approach. Mark suggested to make the glance_keystone_user variable global.
> 
> 
> I guess the question is, which way do you want it. Do we want it set globaly? or do we want it hard coded. If you look at the config file, cinder is hard coded. If we don't want hard coded names then we should move all of hard coded names into the global variable file. But others are going to have to identify what impact that might have.

Using the variable is the correct approach. Some of the *_keystone_user variables are already in group_vars/all.yml, we typically move them there when they are referenced in multiple roles."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-07-20 07:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Superseded by https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/787346'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-05-23 18:00:26.000000000', 'message': 'These changes allow you to check the expected volume status multiple times before throwing an exception.

A case:
- glance-api runs two or more times on separate servers with multiple threads.
- using glance api in HA mode  and cinder as the backend.
- we cannot use multipolar volumes.
- Create a new virtual machine with temporary root disks. nova asks the glance api for the image, the glance api asks the cinder for the volume and the glance api try to mount the volume as a local disk to download nova. Cinder sends a response, and there we indicate a race condition for the two or more glance api servers. All answers from cinder include the volume status "available", but for the first glance of the api it is indeed "available" and for others it is "in-use".

Change-Id: Ib281337e350ea38a2911721a3a5bba2148e7711b

commit_message:
Allow to check the expected volume status multiple times before throwing an exception.

A case:
- glance-api has been run two or more times on different servers with multiple threads.
- using glance api in HA mode  and cinder as the backend.
- we cannot use multiattach volumes.
- Create a new virtual machine with temporary root disks. nova asks the glance api for the image, the glance api asks the cinder for the volume and the glance api try to mount the volume as a local disk to download nova. Cinder sends a response, and there we indicate a race condition for the two or more glance api servers. All answers from cinder include the volume status "available", but for the first glance of the api it is indeed "available" and for others it is "in-use".

Change-Id: Ib281337e350ea38a2911721a3a5bba2148e7711b

commit_message:
Deprecation notice for the 'convert_data' function.

The 'validations_libs.utils.convert_data' function
has lost most of it's original purpose,
as the new CLI is able to perform the same input sanitation
in a better way.

The function is therefore deprecated, and marked for
removal during the Yoga cycle.

Calls of the function with arguments in need of conversion,
that is, from string of comma separated values to list,
will now raise a warning trought standard logging facilities.

Deprecation, along with list of affected APIs, is described
in the function docstring and in generated documentation.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I012e70794b37355096f3b58d3aa2a81ea09640fe

[{'created': '2020-08-12 06:06:42.000000000', 'message': "Deprecate ability to disable cephfs snapshots

Manila doesn't allow users to create snapshots
of their shares unless the cloud operator provides
them the ability via share type extra specs.
Despite this, there was a safety rail in the CephFS
driver to hard disable the snapshot capability,
because snapshots weren't fully supported in older
releases of Ceph.

CephFS snapshots are fully supported by the product
in the Nautilus release [1]. Since Manila does not
support Ceph versions prior to Nautilus from the
Victoria cycle [2], we can safely remove this
unnecessary safety rail. The option is deprecated
in Manila [3], and in puppet-manila [4], and
we can get rid of it from the environment files
we ship with TripleO and deprecate the associated
heat parameter.
[1] https://docs.ceph.com/docs/nautilus/dev/cephfs-snapshots/

[3] https://review.opendev.org/736827/

commit_message:
Deprecate ability to disable cephfs snapshots

Manila doesn't allow users to create snapshots
of their shares unless the cloud operator provides
them the ability via share type extra specs.
Despite this, there was a safety rail in the CephFS
driver to hard disable the snapshot capability,
because snapshots weren't fully supported in older
releases of Ceph.

CephFS snapshots are fully supported by the product
in the Nautilus release [1]. Since Manila does not
support Ceph versions prior to Nautilus from the
Victoria cycle [2], we can safely remove this
unnecessary safety rail. The option is deprecated
in Manila [3], and in puppet-manila [4], and
we can get rid of it from the environment files
we ship with TripleO and deprecate the associated
heat parameter.

[1] https://docs.ceph.com/docs/nautilus/dev/cephfs-snapshots/
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/admin/cephfs_driver.html#ceph-testing-matrix
[3] https://review.opendev.org/736827/
[4] https://review.opendev.org/745766/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/745951
Change-Id: I091c94a2b695ef73bdc4b3d45f2e7f7013b3a638
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Neutron: Set internal certificates in apache

This is a prep work to run neutron-api by httpd, and configure internal
certificates in httpd. The remaining implementation for tls_proxy will
be removed once tripleo-heat-templates is updated.

Change-Id: I3938ec3b0e9845bb163dac03c12df99457972a7a

commit_message:
Replace deprecated Table.copy()

Table.copy() is deprecated since sqlalchemy 1.4 and the method was
renamed to _copy() [1].

[1] https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/2591

Change-Id: If836b3e25788e2252477a384ec5a250aaf5f2041

commit_message:
Replace deprecated import of ABCs from collections

ABCs in collections should be imported from collections.abc and direct
import from collections is deprecated since Python 3.3.

Change-Id: Ibca1d5756d7598e961e21c5ba9bd6e17bb895285

commit_message:
WIP Switch to overcloud-hardened-uefi-full by default on master

WIP because the actual change will remove the inject_images from all
of the config yaml files and turn them into a set_fact in the one role
which uses them.

The following is an arbitrary depends on to trigger building
overcloud-hardened-uefi-full instead of attempting to download it.
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/801226

Change-Id: I7ad59e95b3143a351fc24fc6b73abd58803b0b5b
Blueprint: whole-disk-default

subject: diskfile: don't remove recently written non-durables
messages:
[{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-15 17:10:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-07-15 17:32:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

Yeah, seems reasonable. There's an obvious place to turn it into a config option, but hopefully 60s is enough for most object-servers.

Might be worth an explicit

 Related-Change: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0

in the commit message; we could probably even replace nondurable_purge_delay with a single reclaim_delay (or maybe commit_window?) option that covers both aspects."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-15 18:31:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-15 18:38:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I'd like to find the right bug to link or write up a new one.

I'd also like to understand why Kota wrote on this older patch https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/289756:

"We shouldn't use st_mtime because it may cause flaky statement due to replication timing. i.e. if each node has too different st_mtime for same .data/.durable, it may cause "reclaim->replication->reclaim->replication..." loop."'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2021-07-15 21:08:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

thanks for putting together such great tests Al!!!'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-16 10:18:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-16 12:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-16 16:23:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-07-16 17:46:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)

Yeah, this all seems reasonable.

I think Kota's concern with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/289756 was based on re-using reclaim_age. Operators ought to configure reclaim_age > reconstructor cycle time (and likely something like 10-100x cycle time) -- if commit_window = reclaim_age, you run into a situation where reconstructors complete, operator sees it's safe to rebalance (based either purely on cycle time or considering handoff counts), new ring gets pushed out, so the non-durable/lonely-meta gets moved again and (literally :P) gets a new lease on life. If the cluster's turning over fast enough relative to reclaim_age, it'll *never* get deleted.

I definitely like the separate commit_window configurable, and we might want to call out that you want commit_window << reclaim_age in the sample conf/docs. Speaking of, I suppose we probably ought to update doc/source/config/object_server_config.rst and doc/manpages/object-server.conf.5"}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-19 10:00:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2021-07-19 19:58:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)

Couple minor things about comments in tests, but otherwise LGTM. I'll plan on pushing up a fix later today, assuming you don't get to it."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-19 20:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2021-07-19 20:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-15 17:10:15.000000000', 'message': "WIP diskfile: don't remove recently written non-durables

Change-Id: I5f3318a44af64b77a63713e6ff8d0fd3b6144f13
"}, {'created': '2021-07-15 18:31:56.000000000', 'message': "WIP diskfile: don't remove recently written non-durables

DiskFileManager will remove any stale files during
cleanup_ondisk_files(): these include tombstones and nondurable EC
data fragments whose timestamps are older than reclaim_age. It can
usually be safely assumed that a non-durable data fragment older than
reclaim_age is not going to become durable. However, if an agent PUTs
objects with specified older X-Timestamps (for example the reconciler
or container-sync) then there is a window of time during which the
object server has written an old non-durable data file but has not yet
committed it to make it durable.

Previously, if another process (for example the reconstructor) called
cleanup_ondisk_files during this window then the non-durable data file
would be removed. The subsequent attempt to commit the data file would
then result in a traceback due to there no longer being a data file to
rename, and of course the data file is lost.

This patch modifies cleanup_ondisk_files to not remove old, otherwise
stale, non-durable data files that were only written to disk in the
preceding 'commit_window' seconds. 'commit_window' is configurable for
the object server and defaults to 60 seconds.

Related-Change: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0
Change-Id: I5f3318a44af64b77a63713e6ff8d0fd3b6144f13
"}, {'created': '2021-07-16 10:18:43.000000000', 'message': "diskfile: don't remove recently written non-durables

DiskFileManager will remove any stale files during
cleanup_ondisk_files(): these include tombstones and nondurable EC
data fragments whose timestamps are older than reclaim_age. It can
usually be safely assumed that a non-durable data fragment older than
reclaim_age is not going to become durable. However, if an agent PUTs
objects with specified older X-Timestamps (for example the reconciler
or container-sync) then there is a window of time during which the
object server has written an old non-durable data file but has not yet
committed it to make it durable.

Previously, if another process (for example the reconstructor) called
cleanup_ondisk_files during this window then the non-durable data file
would be removed. The subsequent attempt to commit the data file would
then result in a traceback due to there no longer being a data file to
rename, and of course the data file is lost.

This patch modifies cleanup_ondisk_files to not remove old, otherwise
stale, non-durable data files that were only written to disk in the
preceding 'commit_window' seconds. 'commit_window' is configurable for
the object server and defaults to 60 seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1936508
Related-Change: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0
Change-Id: I5f3318a44af64b77a63713e6ff8d0fd3b6144f13
"}, {'created': '2021-07-16 12:47:20.000000000', 'message': "diskfile: don't remove recently written non-durables

DiskFileManager will remove any stale files during
cleanup_ondisk_files(): these include tombstones and nondurable EC
data fragments whose timestamps are older than reclaim_age. It can
usually be safely assumed that a non-durable data fragment older than
reclaim_age is not going to become durable. However, if an agent PUTs
objects with specified older X-Timestamps (for example the reconciler
or container-sync) then there is a window of time during which the
object server has written an old non-durable data file but has not yet
committed it to make it durable.

Previously, if another process (for example the reconstructor) called
cleanup_ondisk_files during this window then the non-durable data file
would be removed. The subsequent attempt to commit the data file would
then result in a traceback due to there no longer being a data file to
rename, and of course the data file is lost.

This patch modifies cleanup_ondisk_files to not remove old, otherwise
stale, non-durable data files that were only written to disk in the
preceding 'commit_window' seconds. 'commit_window' is configurable for
the object server and defaults to 60.0 seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1936508
Related-Change: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0
Change-Id: I5f3318a44af64b77a63713e6ff8d0fd3b6144f13

commit_message:
diskfile: don't remove recently written non-durables

DiskFileManager will remove any stale files during
cleanup_ondisk_files(): these include tombstones and nondurable EC
data fragments whose timestamps are older than reclaim_age. It can
usually be safely assumed that a non-durable data fragment older than
reclaim_age is not going to become durable. However, if an agent PUTs
objects with specified older X-Timestamps (for example the reconciler
or container-sync) then there is a window of time during which the
object server has written an old non-durable data file but has not yet
committed it to make it durable.

Previously, if another process (for example the reconstructor) called
cleanup_ondisk_files during this window then the non-durable data file
would be removed. The subsequent attempt to commit the data file would
then result in a traceback due to there no longer being a data file to
rename, and of course the data file is lost.

This patch modifies cleanup_ondisk_files to not remove old, otherwise
stale, non-durable data files that were only written to disk in the
preceding 'commit_window' seconds. 'commit_window' is configurable for
the object server and defaults to 60.0 seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1936508
Related-Change: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0
Change-Id: I5f3318a44af64b77a63713e6ff8d0fd3b6144f13

commit_message:
Replace deprecated import of ABCs from collections

ABCs in collections should be imported from collections.abc and direct
import from collections is deprecated since Python 3.3.

Change-Id: Id87b24cbb7050043ae4d6b7aef5ee6a59beec8d9

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-18 13:59:57.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for keystone_authtoken/memcache_use_advanced_pool

This change introduces a single parameter, MemcacheUseAdvancedPool,
to enable usage of advanced connection pool in keystone middleware.
This is useful to avoid bursting connection to memcached.

Note that the default value of memcached_use_advanced_pool was changed
from false to true during Xena cycle[1], so this parameter is no longer
required in master. However the change in keystonemiddleware will
never be backported. This change is created so that we can switch to
advanced pool even in older releases.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystonemiddleware/+/773939

(To Victoria)
Conflicts:
	deployment/aodh/aodh-api-container-puppet.yaml
	deployment/glance/glance-api-container-puppet.yaml
	deployment/gnocchi/gnocchi-api-container-puppet.yaml

commit_message:
Add support for keystone_authtoken/memcache_use_advanced_pool

This change introduces a single parameter, MemcacheUseAdvancedPool,
to enable usage of advanced connection pool in keystone middleware.
This is useful to avoid bursting connection to memcached.

Note that the default value of memcached_use_advanced_pool was changed
from false to true during Xena cycle[1], so this parameter is no longer
required in master. However the change in keystonemiddleware will
never be backported. This change is created so that we can switch to
advanced pool even in older releases.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystonemiddleware/+/773939

(To Victoria)
Conflicts:
	deployment/aodh/aodh-api-container-puppet.yaml
	deployment/glance/glance-api-container-puppet.yaml
	deployment/gnocchi/gnocchi-api-container-puppet.yaml
	deployment/manila/manila-api-container-puppet.yaml
	deployment/nova/nova-api-container-puppet.yaml

Closes-Bug: #1931047
Change-Id: I2887249af44ccfdae1592dd9120d3366fa059876
(cherry picked from commit 09bcacd25a7217ce66eec10ccfda4847e6d3d87a)
(cherry picked from commit 9a89b9add62d1d6251285a091e96e98f8157d1bd)

Convert multi line if statement to case

Having multi-line if-elif statements is not ideal, case improves
readability clarifying the code.

subject: Set glance limit for baremetal friendly images
messages: [{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-07-19 17:36:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2021-07-19 19:01:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nApproving to unblock our CI'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2021-07-19 20:58:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2021-07-19 20:58:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-19 17:36:14.000000000', 'message': 'Set glance limit for baremetal friendly images

The devstack default limit enforcement for glance defaults
to 1GB, and unfortunately this is too small for many to use
larger images such as centos which includes hardware firmware
images for execution on baremetal where drivers need the vendor
blobs in order to load/run.

Sets metalsmith-integration-base to 5GB.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/801309
Change-Id: If3f7cd61ebce5f1724fe4fa56a9bf0e9793d8485
'}]
commit_message:
Set glance limit for baremetal friendly images

The devstack default limit enforcement for glance defaults
to 1GB, and unfortunately this is too small for many to use
larger images such as centos which includes hardware firmware
images for execution on baremetal where drivers need the vendor
blobs in order to load/run.

Sets metalsmith-integration-base to 5GB.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/801309
Change-Id: If3f7cd61ebce5f1724fe4fa56a9bf0e9793d8485

commit_message:
Made dnsmasq.conf overridable in configmap-etc secret

As dnsmasq.conf data in configmap-etc secret was empty, there was no option
to override it. Added the section in the values.yaml file where the dnsmasq.conf
config can be added which will be reflected in dhcp-agent.

Change-Id: If11c33f6f837dbf0d16e54cc92cabf399e773968

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-16 16:09:02.000000000', 'message': 'py3: Replace deprecated import of ABCs from collections

ABCs in collections should be imported from collections.abc and direct
import from collections is deprecated since Python 3.3.
This change ensures that the abstract Mapping class is imported from
collections.abc instead of collections in Python 3 env.

Closes-Bug: #1936667
Change-Id: I9232311784d1feff2d669455dafde17ed9f751ad
'}, {'created': '2021-07-17 03:42:33.000000000', 'message': 'Remove redundant usage of collections(.abc).Mapping

The json.loads method returns a normal python dict without any hook
defined, and type check using the Mapping class is redundant.

In Python 3.8
>>> import json
>>> type(json.loads('{"foo": {"var": "baz"}}'))
<class 'dict'>

In Python 2.7
>>> import json
>>> type(json.loads('{"foo": {"var": "baz"}}'))
<class 'dict'>

With this change we don't have to handle difference between Python 2
and Python 3 and later about import path we should use to import that
abstract class

Closes-Bug: #1936667
Change-Id: I9232311784d1feff2d669455dafde17ed9f751ad
'}]
commit_message:
Remove redundant usage of collections(.abc).Mapping

The json.loads method returns a normal python dict without any hook
defined, and type check using the Mapping class is redundant.

In Python 3.8
>>> import json
>>> type(json.loads('{"foo": {"var": "baz"}}'))
<class 'dict'>

In Python 2.7
>>> import json
>>> type(json.loads('{"foo": {"var": "baz"}}'))
<class 'dict'>

With this change we don't have to handle difference between Python 2
and Python 3 and later about import path we should use to import that
abstract class

Closes-Bug: #1936667
Change-Id: I9232311784d1feff2d669455dafde17ed9f751ad

commit_message:
Remove become: true from the role

The role is always executed with --become, as it is specified in the
documentation. The CLI also invokes the role with --become parameter. In
this case, we were currently implementing a non consistent become
policy. As almost all the tasks in the role require root access, it is
more consistent to remove all the become: true entries and launch the
role with --become parameter.

This is not a fully clean backup as in ussuri the ceph management tasks
are not present.

Depends-on: Id2aff61f219b0c4992f6f0045f1aba2c7d129758
Change-Id: I263e05c905e3ea6f3f25f4e5a1b8dfb25f6a3f97
(cherry picked from commit fad1ea42cea2087e85948ab666978a2c32d60a00)
(cherry picked from commit 6cb6a99c4b56cf4b401d4f5507025095fa937487)

The OctaviaPostWorkflowName parameter used to define name of
the mistral workflow to run post deployment tasks for Octavia. However
all post tasks have been migrated from independent mistral workflow to
external_deploy_task[1], and the parameter has had no effect since
that migration.

[1] 3def4e0384c22e9d7d6821ab74a372d188a2d0ac

commit_message:
Remove unused OctaviaPostWorkflowName

The OctaviaPostWorkflowName parameter used to define name of
the mistral workflow to run post deployment tasks for Octavia. However
all post tasks have been migrated from independent mistral workflow to
external_deploy_task[1], and the parameter has had no effect since
that migration.

[1] 3def4e0384c22e9d7d6821ab74a372d188a2d0ac

Change-Id: I419daa040f5998440af956fadab62ec26abed4dc

[{'created': '2021-07-10 20:11:47.000000000', 'message': "Remove deprecation warnings for the role command

The `role` commands are warning users that they have been deprecated
and informing users that they should use the alternative `roles`
commands. Sadly, we have no such `roles` plugin, so following the
deprecation warning provides false information which results in an
error should the command be used.

This change removes the deprecations warnings for the `role` commands.
If this needs to be refactored later we can; however, given the
information is wrong and there's no alternative plugin to use, making
the UX bad, we're removing the misinformation.

Change-Id: Ie048cdbe52f5b935ddd4b42febb373f9ff96d8d8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Remove deprecation warnings for the role command

The `role` commands are warning users that they have been deprecated
and informing users that they should use the alternative `roles`
commands. Sadly, we have no such `roles` plugin, so following the
deprecation warning provides false information which results in an
error should the command be used.

This change removes the deprecations warnings for the `role` commands.
If this needs to be refactored later we can; however, given the
information is wrong and there's no alternative plugin to use, making
the UX bad, we're removing the misinformation.

Change-Id: Ie048cdbe52f5b935ddd4b42febb373f9ff96d8d8
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove become: true from the role

The role is always executed with --become, as it is specified in the
documentation. The CLI also invokes the role with --become parameter. In
this case, we were currently implementing a non consistent become
policy. As almost all the tasks in the role require root access, it is
more consistent to remove all the become: true entries and launch the
role with --become parameter.

commit_message:
Exclude *.bak files from renaming.

When renaming the nic interfaces, the backup files created were also being
renamed. This caused issues when restoring these backup network-scripts.

Also, this change was part of the docs [0] but it was missed here.

[0] - https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_openstack_platform/16.1/html-single/framework_for_upgrades_13_to_16.1/index#using-predictable-nic-names-preparing-undercloud
Change-Id: Ia5b6893173d54c420c20eeec7cec4eb87b9bfe8f

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-13 16:03:54.000000000', 'message': "[OVN] Fix ML2/OVN + Neutron DHCP agent use case

In an attempt to minimize the number of connections to the OVSDBs the
ML2/OVN driver stopped connecting to the OVN dbs if the Neutron worker
was a RpcWorker but, that introduced a regression for those using
ML2/OVN + Neutron DHCP agent (for baremetal provisioning).

Because the RpcWorker didn't have a connection to the OVN database the
Neutron DHCP agent wasn't able to create the DHCP port and failed with:

2021-07-13 13:36:18.116 17 ERROR neutron.plugins.ml2.managers if not
self._sb_ovn.chassis_exists(host):
2021-07-13 13:36:18.116 17 ERROR neutron.plugins.ml2.managers
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'chassis_exists'

I understand we now have a configuration option [0] which allows us to
make RpcWorker to connect to the database but:

1) It still makes this a regression as the baremetal use case no longer
works by default, operators will need to changing their deployment
script/tool to accomodate to it.

2) We can't backport [0] as it adds a configuration option.

This patch just adds the RpcWorker back to the list of Workers that will
connect to the database.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/795781

Change-Id: I454f3b52376a02f6cc9ca9124083295631bd03d5
Closes-Bug: #1935983
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
"}, {'created': '2021-07-14 10:06:42.000000000', 'message': "[OVN] Fix ML2/OVN + Neutron DHCP agent use case

In an attempt to minimize the number of connections to the OVSDBs the
ML2/OVN driver stopped connecting to the OVN dbs if the Neutron worker
was a RpcWorker but, that introduced a regression for those using
ML2/OVN + Neutron DHCP agent (for baremetal provisioning).

Because the RpcWorker didn't have a connection to the OVN database the
Neutron DHCP agent wasn't able to create the DHCP port and failed with:

2021-07-13 13:36:18.116 17 ERROR neutron.plugins.ml2.managers if not
self._sb_ovn.chassis_exists(host):
2021-07-13 13:36:18.116 17 ERROR neutron.plugins.ml2.managers
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'chassis_exists'

This patch changes the default of the configuration option [0] to
make RpcWorkers connect to the OVN databases by default. That way,
we do not break people that depends on use cases using Neutron DHCP
agent by default and allow others to disable this connection if not
needed.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/795781

Change-Id: I454f3b52376a02f6cc9ca9124083295631bd03d5
Closes-Bug: #1935983
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

2021-07-13 13:36:18.116 17 ERROR neutron.plugins.ml2.managers

This patch adds the RpcWorker back to the list of workers that should

commit_message:
[OVN] Fix ML2/OVN + Neutron DHCP agent use case

In an attempt to minimize the number of connections to the OVSDBs the
ML2/OVN driver stopped connecting to the OVN dbs if the Neutron worker
was a RpcWorker but, that introduced a regression for those using
ML2/OVN + Neutron DHCP agent (for baremetal provisioning).

Because the RpcWorker didn't have a connection to the OVN database the
Neutron DHCP agent wasn't able to create the DHCP port and failed with:

2021-07-13 13:36:18.116 17 ERROR neutron.plugins.ml2.managers if not
self._sb_ovn.chassis_exists(host):
2021-07-13 13:36:18.116 17 ERROR neutron.plugins.ml2.managers
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'chassis_exists'

This patch adds the RpcWorker back to the list of workers that should
connect to the OVN databases.

Change-Id: I454f3b52376a02f6cc9ca9124083295631bd03d5
Closes-Bug: #1929633
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Revert "Config option to enable OVN IDL on other workers"

This reverts commit 66ac943b6435901c163c3050ad41dfcaf36ac11d.

Reason for revert: After discussions with the core reviewers for ML2/OVN
and Neutron folks about this configuration option we understood that we
should just enable RpcWorkers  to connect to the OVN database by default
and later allow rpc_workers to be set to 0 in Neutron (for those looking
for optimizations and that don't need RpcWorkers in their deployment). So
I am proposing a revert for this configuration option.

Change-Id: I73ba195401fff9f832b84633398816383f710b23

commit_message:
Add list_skipped_installer option to tempest playbook

After [1] get merged, it is required to set the list_skip_installer
variable properly to osp and tripleo. Right now, since the default is
tripleo, everything will be working fine. But if you want to distinguish
between osp and tripleo, need to set a ternary if when osp_release is
defined or not, which is exactly what this patch does.

1 - https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-tempest-skiplist/+/789625

Change-Id: I8b181d3316ff595f44ff2fae42a380ca68eb6aa1

subject: Provide override for glance image size limit
messages:
[{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-07-19 14:04:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-07-19 14:07:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Adding Dan Smith as a reviewer as he was the original contributor that put in the change which broke ironic's metalsmith jobs due to the quota limits of 1GB."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2021-07-19 14:24:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2021-07-19 15:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

You might consider keeping the old default of 1GB then override that in your jobs to 5GB with the new var. But I expect 5GB is safe enough.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-07-19 15:36:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> You might consider keeping the old default of 1GB then override that in your jobs to 5GB with the new var. But I expect 5GB is safe enough.

Yeah, I mirrored those off the default limits for things like cinder, which are based on disk image default sizes for things like ceph. Those also weren't tunables, so I didn't make this one either.

I'd say leave the default at 1G and override to whatever you need in a job, especially with it being a variable, personally."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-07-19 16:16:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > You might consider keeping the old default of 1GB then override that in your jobs to 5GB with the new var. But I expect 5GB is safe enough.
> 
> Yeah, I mirrored those off the default limits for things like cinder, which are based on disk image default sizes for things like ceph. Those also weren't tunables, so I didn't make this one either.
> 
> I'd say leave the default at 1G and override to whatever you need in a job, especially with it being a variable, personally.

I can see the point of view that 1GB should be sane and fine, but the fact the addition of the limit has broken something means it is going to be a breaking for others, which is just not great experience wise for someone trying to figure things out and experiment unless they already also happen to know and understand the limits interface, behaviors, and already have the in-depth openstack development knowledge to hunt down what exactly is going on.

I guess I'm also conflicted. If we were a solely ubuntu-centric community, we wouldn't likely have this issue. The Ubuntu images are ~600 MB, where as the Centos Stream images are coming in a 1.3GB at present. Which means, any developer is going to hit a non-specific gateway error when trying to upload a stock centos stream image to glance. I guess it may be delineated if we've turned it on globally for all zuul jobs and it is opt-in only for manual devstack runs, but I didn't dig that far as we can't merge patches in ironic until we've got this sorted."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-07-19 17:17:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-07-19 17:18:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I'll rebase my doc change on top of this to make it easier to discover the procedure for expanding this."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-07-19 17:21:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Review-Priority+2

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2021-07-19 17:40:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2021-07-19 17:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-19 14:04:51.000000000', 'message': "Provide a sane default glance limit

And provide the ability to override the setting.

Limits merged into the devstack gate and Ironic's Metalsmith
project which builds Centos images and use them in CI. While a
low traffic set of jobs, they do end up using a bit more than 1 GB
of storage. Limiting devstack universally to 1GB of storage,
also really prohibits any use with more realistic operating
system images which is a hinderance to developers.

The GLANCE_LIMIT_IMAGE_SIZE_TOTAL variable has been added and can
also be utilized to override a more sane default development/test
limit of 5GB.

Change-Id: Id425aa546f1a5973bae8be9c017782d18f0b4a47
"}, {'created': '2021-07-19 17:17:29.000000000', 'message': 'Provide override for glance image size limit

The glance image size limitation was added and unfortuantely
does prevent larger images from being uploaded to glance. In the
case of all baremetal testing, this value is realistically smaller
than stock "cloud" images which support booting to baremetal with
often requisite firmware blobs, which forces some images over 1GB
in size.

Adds GLANCE_LIMIT_IMAGE_SIZE_TOTAL which allows users who need
larger images to be able to override the default while still
enabling limits enforcement in their deployment. The default
value is 1000.

Change-Id: Id425aa546f1a5973bae8be9c017782d18f0b4a47
'}]
commit_message:
Provide override for glance image size limit

The glance image size limitation was added and unfortuantely
does prevent larger images from being uploaded to glance. In the
case of all baremetal testing, this value is realistically smaller
than stock "cloud" images which support booting to baremetal with
often requisite firmware blobs, which forces some images over 1GB
in size.

Adds GLANCE_LIMIT_IMAGE_SIZE_TOTAL which allows users who need
larger images to be able to override the default while still
enabling limits enforcement in their deployment. The default
value is 1000.

Change-Id: Id425aa546f1a5973bae8be9c017782d18f0b4a47

commit_message:
Add tasks to load tempest tests to be executed on jobs

This is a patch to run the list_allowed on tempest task, to load the
tempest tests to be executed by the jobs. The list_allowed for now will
only be executed when the job does not have the tempest_test_whitelist
defined, otherwise, it will use this as default.

Change-Id: I8bd62e568a085778c2ada4f27dd88588c04cf583

commit_message:
Use legacy image upload for train

Commit 9c6667d9156f7228bc91871db820823485ba94ed
switched to use operators for uploading images on all
releases from train onwards.

Train jobs are no failing deploy, unable to find
the overcloud-full image.

This patch adds train to the relesase that use
the legacy upload script.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/801019

Change-Id: Iabcc33deaa494449799cf5ffe9dca44dcabed52e
Closes-Bug: #1936287

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-29 08:32:34.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Stop installing python bindings from pip

As set out in bug #1933096 these bindings are dynamically built against
the version of libvirt present in the environment at build time.

As a result using a pre-built wheel can cause AttributeError's when the
bindings have previously been built elsewhere against an older version
of libvirt installed on the host. This is currently the case in CentOS 8
stream based CI jobs where we try to use 7.4.0 bindings that appear to
be built against libvirt <= 6.10 leading to bug #1933096.

This change seeks to avoid this by installing the bindings from packages
that will always be built against the correct corresponding version of
libvirt.

Change-Id: I76184c17a776c4e1ecaab9549d9d36c8c07c60fa
Closes-Bug: #1933096
"}, {'created': '2021-06-29 10:53:41.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Stop installing python bindings from pip

stream based CI jobs where we try to use 7.4.0 bindings that appear to
be built against libvirt <= 6.10 leading to bug #1933096.

This change seeks to avoid this by installing the bindings from packages

commit_message:
libvirt: Stop installing python bindings from pip

As set out in bug #1933096 these bindings are dynamically built against
the version of libvirt present in the environment at build time.

As a result using a pre-built wheel can cause AttributeError's when the
bindings have previously been built elsewhere against an older version
of libvirt installed on the host. This is currently the case in CentOS 8
stream based CI jobs where we try to use 7.4.0 bindings that appear to
be built against libvirt <= 6.10 leading to bug #1933096.

This change seeks to avoid this by installing the bindings from packages
that will always be built against the correct corresponding version of
libvirt.

Change-Id: I76184c17a776c4e1ecaab9549d9d36c8c07c60fa
Closes-Bug: #1933096

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Change-Id: Icd090cf8a36fa560bf7b0c67d0e1c4923c221c65
(cherry picked from commit a53ec14ee073cb69e876c4ee29e10ba65b438076)

commit_message:
Pass tripleo_ceph_client_cluster in ceph_client template

When ceph_client.yaml.j2 is built by tripleo_cephadm for
client configuration, we pass the FSID by setting
tripleo_ceph_client_fsid to tripleo_cephadm_fsid but we
were not passing the tripleo_ceph_client_cluster name
the same way which resulted in bug 1935841. This patch
updates ceph_client.yaml.j2 to set the cluster name the
same way that we set the cluster FSID.

Change-Id: I7a8e819858a7d75bb0dd1eb22146916d30eeff0b
Closes-Bug: #1935841
(cherry picked from commit a02213ab1952088ce038825bec161bb3432006dd)

[{'created': '2021-07-08 15:15:27.000000000', 'message': 'Neutron: Use the pids subsystem to look up container id

Currently we rely on cgroup name to detect id of sidecar containers but
the name is not managed by podman and it is not guaranteed that it is

actively managed by podman and more likely to be consistent with
container ids.

commit_message:
Neutron: Use the pids subsystem to look up container id

Currently we rely on cgroup name to detect id of sidecar containers but
the name is not managed by podman and it is not guaranteed that it is
consistent with container id.
This changes switches the base record to the pid subsystem which is
actively managed by podman and more likely to be consistent with
container ids.

Closes-Bug: #1933918
Change-Id: Id57f86e62409e257f5619dc8b360cee3f922c805
(cherry picked from commit b1e992a739057d0b3b72dedeb9e6c47a14f47829)
(cherry picked from commit 8c2862d2307b5be069db4ec4c8d90bc3b31ffbb6)
(cherry picked from commit 46ad1e676d4fcf6025906426e63f801cdcf92d71)
(cherry picked from commit 6a3ebac50a78439c20ba5ccd0c9183a69138448a)

subject: Test override of CephClusterName in 004 standalone
messages:
[{'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2021-07-12 19:28:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-07-13 13:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2021-07-13 14:11:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We see "ceph0" prefixed conf and key files [1] after the name change
showing that the depends-on patch for 1935774 is solves the problem.
We also see evidence of 1935841 not being solved because there are
also "ceph" prefxied conf and key files [1]. I conjecture this is
because this THT patch to test the change does not depend on the
solution to 1935841 [2] but that after all of these patches merge
we will only see "ceph0" prefixed conf and key files. These files
are colliding because in this job CephConfigPath is set to /etc/ceph.
but by default they wouldn't overwrite eachtoher.

[1] https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_b70/800549/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario004-standalone/b7054df/logs/undercloud/etc/ceph/index.html

[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/800525'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2021-07-13 18:24:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The following have merged. Let's see what /etc/ceph looks like with a rerun:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/800525
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/800472"}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2021-07-13 18:24:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2021-07-14 12:22:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> The following have merged. Let's see what /etc/ceph looks like with a rerun:
> 
> https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/800525
> https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/800472

As expected, /etc/ceph now only contains ceph0 prefixed entries so it looks like both patches above had the expected result.

https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_0ec/800549/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario004-standalone/0ec874a/logs/undercloud/etc/ceph/index.html"}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2021-07-19 10:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
cephadm: add missing cluster name

Two tasks were calling `ceph_key` module without the `cluster` parameter
which is problematic in DCN environment, where we specify the cluster
name.

Closes-Bug: #1935774
Change-Id: I2f5647ea9bc219f0eca9b9580662ca4b5c3c226e
(cherry picked from commit b754b17724f5fb3b2ad1f374637acaeb0a7c17a1)

commit_message:
Add OS version to check reboot happened

In some cases OS of VM shuts down very slowly. After post_reboot_delay
(120 sec) ansible logs in to VM and runs "systemctl
is-system-running | grep -qE "running|degraded" which works perfectly on
RHEL/CentOS 7/8. Ansible will be puzzled as it doesn't detect any other
statuses. This issue was solved in ansible 2.10 by redesigning reboot
module where "boot_time_command" verifies boot_id before and after
reboot. However, we cannot backport ansible 2.10 to product so this
patch adds a little check to detect OS version to keep it simple. This
works as leapp installs RHEL8 in disconnected mode after reboot, ansible
won't be able to connect until leapp is done.

Resolves: rhbz#1980542

Change-Id: I6190ee794dce461077b08b486aef18cbf9cc04b3

commit_message:
Online backup of the galera database must desynchronize the node before backup

This fix aims to desynchonize the current node of the galera database to
avoid receiving any writes or syncs from the master node while the
backup is being performed, ensuring the consistency of the dump.

This procedure is specified on the product manual [1].

[1] https://galeracluster.com/library/training/tutorials/galera-backup.html

Closes-Bug: #1934654

Change-Id: I879abd53a17402a0860557d8e0e31ab0c560fcd4
(cherry picked from commit dea5ae05694a64634bfc3df63bc176a1cbeab585)
(cherry picked from commit bf60d71718f442296280080215f2de75cb8271ac)

commit_message:
More descriptive task names

As highlighted by marios on [1] and [2] the task names were
not descriptive of what it was being done, as it implied that some kind
of verification was being done.

This patch does not change any functionality, but it changes the names
of the tasks to something more according to what it is being done.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/791450/12/tripleo_ansible/roles/backup_and_restore/tasks/ceph_authentication.yml

[{'created': '2021-07-19 08:16:17.000000000', 'message': 'Backup and Restore playbook is not 100% idempotent when running in snapshot mode

This fix a small issue that can happen when the user directly cancels
the execution of the playbook when the rear backup is happening. After

commit_message:
Backup and Restore playbook is not 100% idempotent when running in snapshot mode

This fix a small issue that can happen when the user directly cancels
the execution of the playbook when the rear backup is happening. After
that, the node remains disconnected from pacemaker and it is necessary
to add it back to the cluster so the mysql-galera container is running
when we do the mysql dump.

As the pcs cluster start is an idempotent command in itself, we do not
need to perform a verification check before running it nor it will
generate errors (return 1) when ran if it was already running.

Closes-Bug: #1934897

Change-Id: I9a425665f4714751d8b1a0bd381533e4c383df9d
(cherry picked from commit aa93f9d7a05d33bdf0aa6177da10f51a1e784bc2)
(cherry picked from commit a22d8d9817e07b76ccd83211659fea55796b735b)

commit_message:
Backup and Restore playbook is not 100% idempotent when running in snapshot mode

This fix a small issue that can happen when the user directly cancels
the execution of the playbook when the rear backup is happening. After
that, the node remains disconnected from pacemaker and it is necessary
to add it back to the cluster so the mysql-galera container is running
when we do the mysql dump.

As the pcs cluster start is an idempotent command in itself, we do not
need to perform a verification check before running it nor it will
generate errors (return 1) when ran if it was already running.

Closes-Bug: #1934897

Change-Id: I9a425665f4714751d8b1a0bd381533e4c383df9d

commit_message:
Additional fields for Create/Update Share Type forms

Create Share Type and Update Share Type forms have a general text field
for all extra specs. This patch adds choice fields for the required one
'driver_handles_share_servers' and for the optional one with a default
value -- 'snapshot_support'. Since the values are boolean now, the patch
also removes the redundant validation and some help text remarks.
Invalid form problem is also fixed and error handling works properly.

Change-Id: I5a158d082b2f9fd5f99a220e50e1920cd2005c14
Closes-Bug: #1599788
Closes-Bug: #1584145

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-13 15:06:15.000000000', 'message': "Update default Debian paths for Buster and newer

Since version 10 (Buster) the package openstack-dashboard installs its
files to different directories than it used to. With version 11
(Bullseye) just about to reach stable status, it might be time to update
the defaults.

Note that this also some of the paths for RHEL - there used to be two
hard-coded paths in the recipes/horizon.rb which no longer work under
modern Debian.

PS. The permission change on dash_state_dir is part of this too,
since without o+x Apache complains

access to /static/foo denied (filesystem path '/var/lib/openstack-dashboard/static') because search permissions are missing on a component of the path

whenever any static dashboard content is to be retrieved.

Signed-off-by: Marek Szuba <m.szuba@gsi.de>
Change-Id: I345b4894f1243db77856303d97538914dc6cf9be
"}, {'created': '2021-07-13 15:51:45.000000000', 'message': "Update default Debian paths for Buster and newer

Since version 10 (Buster) the package openstack-dashboard installs its
files to different directories than it used to. With version 11
(Bullseye) just about to reach stable status, it might be time to update
the defaults.

Note that this also some of the paths for RHEL - there used to be two
hard-coded paths in the recipes/horizon.rb which no longer work under
modern Debian.

PS. The permission change on dash_state_dir is part of this too,
since without o+x Apache complains

access to /static/foo denied (filesystem path '/var/lib/openstack-dashboard/static') because search permissions are missing on a component of the path

whenever any static dashboard content is to be retrieved.

Signed-off-by: Marek Szuba <m.szuba@gsi.de>
Change-Id: I345b4894f1243db77856303d97538914dc6cf9be
"}, {'created': '2021-07-13 16:28:58.000000000', 'message': "Update default Debian paths for Buster and newer

Since version 10 (Buster) the package openstack-dashboard installs its
files to different directories than it used to. With version 11
(Bullseye) just about to reach stable status, it might be time to update
the defaults.

Note that this also changes the handling of some of the paths for RHEL
- there used to be two hard-coded paths in the recipes/horizon.rb which
still work under RHEL but not under modern Debian, requiring a switch to
attribute-defined paths.

PS. The permission change on dash_state_dir is part of this too,
since without o+x Apache complains

access to /static/foo denied (filesystem path '/var/lib/openstack-dashboard/static') because search permissions are missing on a component of the path

whenever any static dashboard content is to be retrieved.

Signed-off-by: Marek Szuba <m.szuba@gsi.de>
Change-Id: I345b4894f1243db77856303d97538914dc6cf9be
"}, {'created': '2021-07-15 20:25:01.000000000', 'message': "Update default Debian paths for Buster and newer

Since version 10 (Buster) the package openstack-dashboard installs its
files to different directories than it used to. With version 11
(Bullseye) just about to reach stable status, it might be time to update
the defaults.

Note that this also changes the handling of some of the paths for RHEL
- there used to be two hard-coded paths in the recipes/horizon.rb which
still work under RHEL but not under modern Debian, requiring a switch to

PS. The permission change on dash_state_dir is part of this too,
since without o+x Apache complains

access to /static/foo denied (filesystem path '/var/lib/openstack-dashboard/static') because search permissions are missing on a component of the path

whenever any static dashboard content is to be retrieved.

Signed-off-by: Marek Szuba <m.szuba@gsi.de>
Change-Id: I345b4894f1243db77856303d97538914dc6cf9be
"}, {'created': '2021-07-19 13:01:08.000000000', 'message': "Update default Debian paths for Buster and newer

Since version 10 (Buster) the package openstack-dashboard installs its
files to different directories than it used to. With version 11
(Bullseye) just about to reach stable status, it might be time to update
the defaults - for Debian proper anyway, since judging from the contents
of relevant Ubuntu 21.04 packages that distro has decided to go their
own way here.

Note that this also changes the handling of some of the paths for RHEL
- there used to be two hard-coded paths in the recipes/horizon.rb which
still work under RHEL and Ubuntu but not under modern Debian, requiring
a switch to attribute-defined paths.

PS. The permission change on dash_state_dir is part of this too,
since without o+x Apache complains

access to /static/foo denied (filesystem path '/var/lib/openstack-dashboard/static') because search permissions are missing on a component of the path

whenever any static dashboard content is to be retrieved.

Signed-off-by: Marek Szuba <m.szuba@gsi.de>
Change-Id: I345b4894f1243db77856303d97538914dc6cf9be

commit_message:
Update default Debian paths for Buster and newer

Since version 10 (Buster) the package openstack-dashboard installs its
files to different directories than it used to. With version 11
(Bullseye) just about to reach stable status, it might be time to update
the defaults - for Debian proper anyway, since judging from the contents
of relevant Ubuntu 21.04 packages that distro has decided to go their
own way here.

Note that this also changes the handling of some of the paths for RHEL
- there used to be two hard-coded paths in the recipes/horizon.rb which
still work under RHEL and Ubuntu but not under modern Debian, requiring
a switch to attribute-defined paths.

PS. The permission change on dash_state_dir is part of this too,
since without o+x Apache complains

access to /static/foo denied (filesystem path '/var/lib/openstack-dashboard/static') because search permissions are missing on a component of the path

whenever any static dashboard content is to be retrieved.

Signed-off-by: Marek Szuba <m.szuba@gsi.de>
Change-Id: I345b4894f1243db77856303d97538914dc6cf9be

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-15 10:43:10.000000000', 'message': "Explicitly set ceph_dashboard_vip when Ceph Dashboard is enabled

When the Ceph Dashboard environment file is added, the haproxy config
is created for both the ceph dashboard and the monitoring stack (made
by grafana, prometheus, alertmanager, node-exporter).
We used to have the 'ceph_dashboard_vip' rely to the ctlplane network
unless the StorageDashboard composable network is explicitly added to
the overcloud deployment.
This patch, instead, explicitly sets the ceph_dashboard_vip using the
'CephDashboardNetwork' parameter defined in tripleo-heat-templates.
By doing this the operator has the flexibility to use the network
defined via tht to reach the Ceph Dashboard, resulting in a more
consistent configuration according to the user expectations.

Change-Id: Icc68dad8074dd02d84f76efac45ed08b42a2bd2f
(cherry picked from commit 5dc5cdb62639fc240fd44b50b5322888fc40efc3)
"}]
commit_message:
Explicitly set ceph_dashboard_vip when Ceph Dashboard is enabled

When the Ceph Dashboard environment file is added, the haproxy config
is created for both the ceph dashboard and the monitoring stack (made
by grafana, prometheus, alertmanager, node-exporter).
We used to have the 'ceph_dashboard_vip' rely to the ctlplane network
unless the StorageDashboard composable network is explicitly added to
the overcloud deployment.
This patch, instead, explicitly sets the ceph_dashboard_vip using the
'CephDashboardNetwork' parameter defined in tripleo-heat-templates.
By doing this the operator has the flexibility to use the network
defined via tht to reach the Ceph Dashboard, resulting in a more
consistent configuration according to the user expectations.

Change-Id: Icc68dad8074dd02d84f76efac45ed08b42a2bd2f
(cherry picked from commit 5dc5cdb62639fc240fd44b50b5322888fc40efc3)

instances with names containing freeform characters alongside
openstack-designate service for neutron.

Also, adding a config feature flag to enable/disable the test.

Devstack gate test:

Change-Id: Ic97bcc033f30da9c6f3c89ed57834b9c3f433b02
'}]
commit_message:
Add test to verify FQDN hostname sanitization

This scenario has impacted field engineers trying to spin up
instances with names containing freeform characters alongside
openstack-designate service for neutron.

Also, adding a config feature flag to enable/disable the test.

Relates to https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1581977 and
gerrit https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/764482/

Devstack gate test:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/801356

Change-Id: Ic97bcc033f30da9c6f3c89ed57834b9c3f433b02

commit_message:
Move lazy store update to locations layer

The authorization layer was hijacked (IMHO) to provide the location
metadata lazy-loading. Since we are disabling that layer in the
policy refactor, we need somewhere else to do that. The best place
to do it seems to be in the actual locations layer of the onion,
so this patch moves it there.

No tests are changed in this patch because this is already confirmed
from the images resource, this just moves where it's done, and not
needing any test change shows that this doesn't change any externally-
visible behavior.

Change-Id: I70372c44f4b2d9547cb8c40b43df17d1085ef03c

commit_message:
Add parameters for image copy when using multiple RBD Glance stores

Expose the Nova config options to allow an image to be automatically
copied into the local Glance store when Glance is configured to use
multiple RBD stores.

Related Nova change: Ia839ad418b0f2887cb8e8f5ee3e660a0751db9ce

Change-Id: I227f40111591cfe1026ce992b3de3e28d092f329

commit_message:
Update requirements

Update minimum required versions of python packages.
The updates is based on crosscheck requirements from required
packages:

oslo-policy 3.7.0 depends on oslo.context>=2.22.0

increase oslo-service version to be able to use eventlet 0.26.0
oslo-service 1.24.0 depends on eventlet!=0.18.3, !=0.20.1, <0.21.0 and >=0.18.2

increase oslo-log version to fix error:
AttributeError: type object 'deprecated' has no attribute 'WALLABY'

oslo-log 4.3.0 depends on oslo.serialization>=2.25.0
oslo-log 4.3.0 depends on pbr>=3.1.1
oslo-log 4.3.0 depends on oslo.i18n>=3.20.0

Change-Id: I20a5a20b94ffd27ea34f23ac89ca2826eb548b1a

commit_message:
Allow list values for enabled_extensions_admin/v2

The following parameters are defined as "ListOpt"s which accept
comma-separated lists.
 service:api/enabled_extensions_admin
 service:api/enabled_extensions_v2

This change makes sure that list values are converted to string
properly to accept list values in the corresponding designate::api
parameters.

Change-Id: I6c18016bf33791e953f708b0f6abf772a434d74f

subject: [L3] Use processing queue for network update events
messages:
[{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-07-07 10:03:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2021-07-07 11:34:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/799781/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 29m 27s'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2021-07-07 13:37:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Nice that we do sync by specific router ID'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2021-07-07 15:05:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm fine with this patch.

However I think we should use the sync mechanism implemented in the L3 agent (the same as in the DHCP agent).

All RPC calls generate a "queue.ResourceUpdate" object with an action. Those actions, stored in self._queue, are executed using the router ID to exclude other actions to be executed in parallel (there is not such concept).

But "update_network" is the only RPC pubsub message attended. That will be processed as soon as is received, as you detected in the logs. As reported, the network update event was processed during the port creation.

        consumers = [[topics.NETWORK, topics.UPDATE]]
        agent_rpc.create_consumers([self], topics.AGENT, consumers)


IMO we should use the implemented mechanism:
- When the "network_update" event is received, create a "queue.ResourceUpdate" object, with a new action (NETWORK_UPDATE, for example). This object must have the router_id parameter.
- Change the code in "L3NATAgent._process_router_update" to process this new action. When this action is received, the code that you have implemented in "_router_network_update" could be used.

--------------------

NOTE (out of scope): IMO, we should remove the multithread in the agents. It doesn't make sense to have worker threads, as we try here. We can have multiple threads listening to events (HTTP events, for example). But only one thread will be executed at the same time in Python. Because there is no real multithreading, I see no benefit on this. The RPC thread can be in change of listening any message or update sent while the main thread, using the ordered_by_resource queue, can process those events.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2021-07-07 15:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I am fine with this lock solution'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2021-07-07 15:47:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> --------------------
> 
> NOTE (out of scope): IMO, we should remove the multithread in the agents. It doesn't make sense to have worker threads, as we try here. We can have multiple threads listening to events (HTTP events, for example). But only one thread will be executed at the same time in Python. Because there is no real multithreading, I see no benefit on this. The RPC thread can be in change of listening any message or update sent while the main thread, using the ordered_by_resource queue, can process those events.

AFAIU currently there could be several python threads processing different routers in "parallel": it's not true multithreading as you said, but still we can benefit when one thread performs time consuming syscall and switches context to other threads meanwhile. If have only one thread processing all routers we'll lose this benefit, meaning thread will be idle while waiting on each syscall. Am I missing something?'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-07-08 08:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> I'm fine with this patch.
> 
> However I think we should use the sync mechanism implemented in the L3 agent (the same as in the DHCP agent).
> 
> All RPC calls generate a "queue.ResourceUpdate" object with an action. Those actions, stored in self._queue, are executed using the router ID to exclude other actions to be executed in parallel (there is not such concept).
> 
> But "update_network" is the only RPC pubsub message attended. That will be processed as soon as is received, as you detected in the logs. As reported, the network update event was processed during the port creation.
> 
>         consumers = [[topics.NETWORK, topics.UPDATE]]
>         agent_rpc.create_consumers([self], topics.AGENT, consumers)
> 
> 
> IMO we should use the implemented mechanism:
> - When the "network_update" event is received, create a "queue.ResourceUpdate" object, with a new action (NETWORK_UPDATE, for example). This object must have the router_id parameter.
> - Change the code in "L3NATAgent._process_router_update" to process this new action. When this action is received, the code that you have implemented in "_router_network_update" could be used.
> 

I changed it locally to what You proposed but that won't solve original issue as there is more workers which can process router_create and network_update events in (kind of) parallel. So the problem that network_update will be called before internal_ports cache is updated may still happend and lock is still needed.
Do You think we should move to the events queue with network update now? Or can it be done in follow up?

> --------------------
> 
> NOTE (out of scope): IMO, we should remove the multithread in the agents. It doesn't make sense to have worker threads, as we try here. We can have multiple threads listening to events (HTTP events, for example). But only one thread will be executed at the same time in Python. Because there is no real multithreading, I see no benefit on this. The RPC thread can be in change of listening any message or update sent while the main thread, using the ordered_by_resource queue, can process those events.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2021-07-08 09:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > I'm fine with this patch.
> > 
> > However I think we should use the sync mechanism implemented in the L3 agent (the same as in the DHCP agent).
> > 
> > All RPC calls generate a "queue.ResourceUpdate" object with an action. Those actions, stored in self._queue, are executed using the router ID to exclude other actions to be executed in parallel (there is not such concept).
> > 
> > But "update_network" is the only RPC pubsub message attended. That will be processed as soon as is received, as you detected in the logs. As reported, the network update event was processed during the port creation.
> > 
> >         consumers = [[topics.NETWORK, topics.UPDATE]]
> >         agent_rpc.create_consumers([self], topics.AGENT, consumers)
> > 
> > 
> > IMO we should use the implemented mechanism:
> > - When the "network_update" event is received, create a "queue.ResourceUpdate" object, with a new action (NETWORK_UPDATE, for example). This object must have the router_id parameter.
> > - Change the code in "L3NATAgent._process_router_update" to process this new action. When this action is received, the code that you have implemented in "_router_network_update" could be used.
> > 
> 
> I changed it locally to what You proposed but that won't solve original issue as there is more workers which can process router_create and network_update events in (kind of) parallel. So the problem that network_update will be called before internal_ports cache is updated may still happend and lock is still needed.
> Do You think we should move to the events queue with network update now? Or can it be done in follow up?
> 
> > --------------------
> > 
> > NOTE (out of scope): IMO, we should remove the multithread in the agents. It doesn't make sense to have worker threads, as we try here. We can have multiple threads listening to events (HTTP events, for example). But only one thread will be executed at the same time in Python. Because there is no real multithreading, I see no benefit on this. The RPC thread can be in change of listening any message or update sent while the main thread, using the ordered_by_resource queue, can process those events.

But if you use "queue.ResourceUpdate" with the router ID, only one thread processing events for this router ID (router create, network update) can be executed at the same time. If that is happening, then the currently implemented mechanism is broken (and is used in L3 and DHCP agents).

I'll remove my -1 but I'll check it myself.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-07-08 10:25:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:
